user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_dispatch:
```c
void metal_softirq_dispatch(void)
{
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < metal_softirq_num; i++) {
		struct metal_irq *irq;
		char is_pending = 1;

		if (atomic_load(&metal_softirq_enabled[i]) != 0 &&
		    atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&metal_softirq_pending[i],
						   &is_pending, 0)) {
			irq = &metal_softirqs[i];
			(void)metal_irq_handle(irq,
					       i + metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base);
		}
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&metal_softirq_pending[i],
				   &is_pending, 0)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the call is to atomic_compare_exchange_strong and there is no evidence it calls metal_softirq_dispatch (directly or indirectly). Rule 17.2 is not violated by this fragment. A concrete violation scenario would exist only if atomic_compare_exchange_strong (or any function it calls) eventually invoked metal_softirq_dispatch, producing indirect recursion, which is not shown here.
